intro: Peucedanum terebinthaceum var. paishanense, commonly known as the Paishan mountain angelica, is a rare and endangered plant species native to the mountainous regions of China. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its tall, slender stem and large, compound leaves. The plant produces small, white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of its family. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in forested areas at high elevations. Due to habitat loss and overharvesting, it is critically endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
